PROFESSOR: So today we're
going to talk about RKR

and a few other things. Before I start, though,
I want to refer you

to two wonderful documents
that are produced by Bob Leroy.

And you can get
them at his website.

And the two that I have here,
one is a program called-- is a document called RKR1.

I don't know whether
it's RKR1 now, because this is dated 1992. But it is the
definitive RKR program.

And you can download it. And whatever-- it contains the
write up of what the RKR is,

which is nominally the
purpose of this lecture. But also, it's a
program that works.

And there's also a
thing called level. And level, among other things,
starts with the potential

and calculates the vibrational
wave function and anything else

that you would calculate from
expectation values or overlaps of vibrational wave functions.

And again, this is the
definitive numerical integration routine
for diatomic molecules.

And so, these are two
incredibly important tools

in diatomic molecule
spectroscopy. And Bob Leroy really owns them.

And there are a
couple of other areas that Leroy is the key person.

And so, it would be a good
idea to obtain these documents.

And in previous
years, I would always assign some kind of a
problem where you would have

to use both of those programs. And I don't have the heart
to do that this year. So I'm just going to say, look
at them and maybe use them.

So you have approached
the energy levels

of diatomic molecules
using perturbation theory. And part of the reason
that I spent a lot of time

on this kind of perturbation
theory treatment is that everything you
do using perturbation

theory on diatomic
molecules transfers to polyatomic molecules.

There is an exact procedure
for relating the energy levels to the potential energy
curve in diatomic molecules.

And that's called RKR. And that does not transfer
to polyatomic molecules.

So it's a little bit
of a bait and switch. If I were to tell
you, only use RKR because it works and is
wonderful, because you

won't be able to take it over. And so, that's why I invested
so much in perturbation theory.

Now, one reason
you would not just

use perturbation
theory on diatomics is because they're
not accurate enough.

That you really
want to represent all observable properties and
relationships between them

as accurately as possible
through one common thing. And that is the
potential energy curve.

And if you use
perturbation theory,

you make a good approximation
to the potential energy curve near the bottom. And the higher up
you go, the more

you don't really know how
good it is what you've built.

So RKR, Rydberg-Klein-Rees,
is a direct product

of WKB,
Wentzel-Kramers-Brillouin. This is a
semi-classical approach.

It is a fantastic
thing, fantastic tool. And it is relevant, at least
in little bits of analysis

for polyatomic molecules. You are able to determine the
shape of the wave function--

qualitative features
of the wave function without solving a
Schrodinger equation.

So basically, all
you need to know is what is the kinetic energy
at a particular point in space.

Now, that's not a
quantum mechanical idea. That's a quantum
mechanical impossibility.

But classically,
you can ask, well, what is the momentum
anywhere in space,

or what is the kinetic energy? And now, for a
diatonic molecule,

kinetic energy is
a scalar quantity. Momentum is a vector quantity. And one can ignore the
fact, because there's

only one direction. But in a polyatomic molecule,
what you really want is momentum.

And that's a vector quantity, or
it's-- and what you have really

is the distance of the energy
above the potential surface.

And that's a kinetic energy. And so, you have to be careful. But let's look at WKB
for a little while.

Because this is such
a wonderful thing.

So semi-classical means
that we can define momentum

classically. And this is not the quantum
mechanical momentum.

But it's a function, it's a
perfectly legitimate function. We could calculate
expectation values of it.
But the momentum is--

well, the kinetic energy
is p squared over 2 mu.

This is the reduced mass. And so, to get p, you
have 2 mu E minus v of r.

So that's the classical
momentum function.

The WKB wave function,
which you can

derive by making some
clever expansion,

where basically, you
get quantum mechanics-- the classical
mechanics, if h is zero

and you get quantum
mechanics otherwise,

the WKB wave function
is this minus 1/2.

So this is an envelope function. And this is the
oscillatory function.

And this is a turning point. And so, you're integrating this
classical momentum function in

from a turning point
to where you want to look at the wave function. And the larger this p is,
the faster this exponential

wiggles. And if you have functions
that are oscillating rapidly,

and you have integrals involving
functions that are oscillating rapidly, the only place where
the integral accumulates

is where the two things
are oscillating rapidly at the same frequency. And so, this is an
extremely important thing.

Because it gives you causality. It gives you-- this
is where if something

is-- if you're using these
kinds of wave functions, and you're calculating the
expectation value of something,

you can think that the
expectation value of something is due to something that
occurred in a particular region

of space. And this is the way we think
about the classical world. And so, this oscillatory
thing is amazingly important,

because it gets you back
to classical mechanisms.
And you've heard of--

and I won't talk about that. And this is the envelope. So the faster
something is moving,

the smaller this factor is. And again, that comes out
of a probabilistic idea.

If something is moving fast,
it doesn't spend much time in a particular place.

And you can actually
work out what the envelope function ought
to be based on calculating--
OK, suppose you have--  we have motion in a potential.

If you can calculate what
the period of oscillation is, and you can calculate,
say, how long it takes

to go through a particular
region of space, if you know the
momentum at that point,

you can calculate how long
it takes to go through this. And the ratio of that
time to the period

or to half the period
tells you the probability of finding the system in
this point, in this region.

And so, the probability
is proportional to 1

over the momentum. And the probability
amplitude, which

is what the wave function
is, is square root of that. So we have something
that it tells

you what is the
probability of finding a system in a particular region
of space and how it oscillates.

And these two are enough to
build an incredible amount of insight.

So now, we have a problem
that we're at some energy.

And we have a wave function,
the WKB wave function, which it turns out is valid
away in a region of space

not near a turning point. Because at a turning point, the
momentum is zero and this blows

up. And that's [? unphysical. ?] And so, if we wanted to use
WKB to describe energy levels,

we have a little
bit of a problem. We're OK outside in the
non-classical region of the potential.

And but in the
non-classical region, the wave function has
to go to 0 at infinity.
And that's a boundary condition. And we're OK inside.

But we have wave functions
propagating inside. And they have to meet and be--

and where these two
wave functions meet, the wave function
has to be continuous.

And so, first of
all, the way you deal with this gap
at the boundary

is that you discover
that you can approximate this region
here as a linear potential

if you're close to it. And then you have wave
functions that are--

or they're area functions-- area
functions are the correct wave function for a linear potential.

And so, with area functions,
you can go across this region. And you join up
these two things.

The wave function having
to go to 0 at infinity--

positive and negative infinity-- imposes a definite phase. And what you end
up discovering is

that the wave function
at a point where the WKB is valid on the
inside of the potential

is the WKB wave
function you would have calculated from here. But it's not valid
here, plus pi over 4--

with a phase of pi over 4. So it's a long, complicated
lecture explaining

how you join the wave-- you get the correct
wave function. And joining across the boundary
is a really important piece

of that. I won't do that. Then, the continuity,
that leads to what's

called the
quantization condition. Because the only
way wave functions,

which go to 0 at
infinity, correctly can be legitimate solutions
is if the two wave

functions are continuous and
the derivative is continuous. And so, you end up getting
a quantization condition.

And the quantization
condition is--
I'm going to put the--

so this is the
quantization condition. This is an integral. This quantity is--
did I blow a sign?
No, that's right. This is the classical momentum.
So it's an integral pdq or pdr.

This pq has the dimension of
H. It's also a quantity that
is known as action. Now, a personal story.

I was an undergraduate
at Amherst College. And we all write theses. And we have a thesis defense.

And at my thesis
defense, Dick Fink, who was a young assistant
professor at the time,

asked me a question which
was, what is the unit of H?
And I said, energy times time. And I was right.

But he didn't want that. He wanted action. And we went around
for half an hour. I was absolutely certain that I
knew what the units of H were.

And he was determined
to get action. And we never converged.

But anyway, this is
an action integral. And basically, the
quantization condition says,

there's a certain
allowed amount of action that at each energy
level, the action integral
is an integral number.
So if we kill the--

so if we make this just H
over 2 to v plus 1, or H times

v plus 1/2, that looks
a little more familiar.

So there's a 1/2
integer amount of action when you evaluate the action
integral at the energy

of an energy level. And there's also-- you get
for each additional level,

there's another H of action.  And so, this is a
very useful quantity.

And the RKR is built
on the action integral.

So the derivation
of the RKR method

is mathematically
opaque, especially when I have to present
it in a lecture.

And there are many different
ways of motivating it.

They all say, let's
start with some function

of energy and rotation. And these lecture notes
were written in 1975
and revised over the years. My book was written in 1990--
2004, sorry. And it's better in my book.

And I don't know why I
didn't do this earlier. So we can describe this
function by the quantity
that appears on as--

where is it-- equation
22 on page four.

So we can just define a as
this function, 2 mu over h bar

squared, square root 1
over pi r minus r plus.

And these are
functions of energy.

E minus Ur minus h bar
squared over 2 mu r
squared J, J plus 1 dr.

So this-- what is this? This here is the
centrifugal potential.

This is V of J of
r, this combination.

And so, you have
the bare potential and you have the
centrifugal correction.

And so, this difference
is the energy.

So if we have the potential
like this, this is the energy, a is just the area.
That's why it's called a.

No, there's some
other stuff to make it dimensionally consistent. So we have a
function that we are

going to play with
two different ways. One way gives us r
minus and r plus at E.

So if we knew what
a was, then we

could do something and derive
values for the turning points from it.

And the other way
of processing this is to find out what
a is based on what

we know from spectra, which are
the vibrational and rotational

constants. So we determine this
from the spectrum. G of V is omega V plus a
1/2, et cetera, et cetera.

And this is bE minus alpha
EV plus 1/2 plus whatever.

And so, we take
this thing and we approach it two different ways.

One gives us turning
points if we knew that. And the other gives us
that if we knew this.

So this to that is
where we want to go.

Bob Leroy says, that the
best way to learn about RKR

is to read Klein's paper,
probably in German, from 1932.

And that he says
also that there's

a paper by Kirchner
and Watson, this is Jim Watson who is as
close to God and spectroscopy

as you can get. He says, that this
was de-discovered.

In other words,
Watson and Kirchner wrote basically Klein's
paper again in 1992.

And so, it might be almost
as good to read the Kirchner and Watson paper.

But anyway-- and
Leroy does not like the way I developed
this by saying,

OK, let's consider this
function and process it two different ways. But I've been doing
this all my life.

And I'm just unable
to escape that. Now, there's given
this function,

it's an exceedingly easy
thing to make the connection between this and that.

That's a couple of steps. The other thing of showing
how you can build these two

things into determine that
is mathematically tedious. And involves all sorts of stuff.

And I'm not going to do that. But the lecture
notes do do that.

So let's just take a
look at this function. And suppose we take
the derivative,

the partial derivative
of a with respect to E.

So we get all sorts of
garbage out in front.
And now, we have an integral.

And so, we're going to
take the derivative. And this isn't E. That's E that
we take the derivative as 1.

So we get the
constants out in front. And then we have integral
r plus r minus V r--
that's pretty easy integral.

Even I can do that one. And so, that gives us
this constant times r plus of E minus r minus of
E. So the first integral,

or the first equation,
we get the derivative--

this derivative
of this area just gives us the
difference in turning
points, which is a nice thing.

And now, let's look at
the partial derivative of a with respect to
J. Well, where is J?
Well, J only appears here. So these two terms go away. And we get 2J plus 1 times that.

So we get all that
constant stuff. And we have an integral.

And we can take minus h
bar squared over 2 mu out.

And we can take 2J plus 1 out. And we have now the integral
from r minus to r plus of 1

over r squared dr.
And this gives us--

this integral gives us 1 over-- so this is equal to minus 1 over
r plus minus 1 over r minus.
I'm very bad at integration.

Even something simple like this. So we have the
minus sign canceling

the minus sign I took out here. And we get now an
integral that involves--

so we have one integral that's
the difference in turning points at E. And this is the
difference in the reciprocal

of the two turning points at
E. Two unknowns, two equations,

bam, you've got it. And so, if we can
know a of EJ, we

can determine the turning points
r plus of EJ and r minus of EJ.
And that's what RKR is.

So I won't go through
the derivation.

Because it's-- I don't like it. It's tedious. It involves a change of
variable and integration

by parts and all sorts
of stuff that you can do. And you wouldn't want to
see that on a blackboard

from someone who is
uncomfortable doing it. And so, what you discover
is that r plus minus r minus

is equal to 2 h bar squared
over 2 mu square root integral,

over the vibrational
quantum number.

That's J. So the
difference in two

turning points is given by-- at E. And E can be
treated as continuous.

This is the inversion of E of V. And so, this can also be treated
as a continuous function.

So you can determine
r plus minus r

minus as a continuous function
of V if you know g of E,

or our continuous function
of E. So this is one thing. And so, you do do that.

And you can have something like
this from polyatomic molecules too. So what is this doing?

It's telling you what is
the width of the potential.

And that's mostly
what you want to know. It would be nice to know where
this is and where this is.

But the difference between them
is the most important thing. Because often, you're willing to
say, I'm going to use a model,

not a model that's completely
free, a model that is saying,

what is the qualitative
form of the potential? And the difference between
the two turning points is all you need in order
to pin down the model.

And that could be done
for polyatomic molecules. One of the problems is
what is the potential?

What are the coordinates? Because you are observing energy
levels, their energy levels

or their levels in state space. There is nothing
about the coordinates. And so, there's all sorts of
problems of saying, OK, well,

we would like a
one-dimensional to cut through a potential surface. But there's all sorts of
issues of, well, yeah,

we could determine the
width of the potential along some one-dimensional
cut, but we don't

know what the coordinates are. So this is interesting. And it's kind of an area where
some insight might be gotten

for polyatomic molecules. And the other one is 1 over
r plus minus 1 over r minus.

And that's, again, we got
this same kind of stuff. I don't know whether--

except the 2 over-- 2 mu over [INAUDIBLE]
bar squared, square root.
And now we have--

so here is an integral
involving a combination of the rotational
constant function and the vibrational energies.

And again, if you
know these functions, and you can pretend that
they're continuous variable--

a continuous function of V,
it's determined point-wise. But so, you can determine
this integral at any energy.

And so, you have this
difference of turning points at any energy.

And so, between the
two, you've got it. Now, this is why you can't
even think about using

this for polyatomic molecules. Because this is the
rotational constant

for one-dimensional oscillator. And for a polyatomic
molecule, you

have three rotational constants. They're all a function
of displacements.

They're all affected
in different ways by displacements along
normal coordinates.

You can take derivatives
of the a, b, and c,

or the inertial constants in
the a, b, and c directions. And so, you can show how
the rotational constants

would change with respect to
the vibrational excitation. But you can't do
something like this.

There is no sensible way. Yes? AUDIENCE: What if
you have a acetylene, where there is only
one rotational constant

[INAUDIBLE]? PROFESSOR: Yes, but you still
have seven vibrational degrees

of freedom of which-- and so, what potential
are you sampling?

So you can do this,
you can't do that.
This might be useful.

Now, there are all
sorts of issues with these kinds of functions.

At the upper turning
point here, the energy

is equal to the
vibrational energy.
And so, this is zero.

The integrand goes to infinity. And so, there is a
singularity in this integral

at the upper limit
of integration. No problem. But it's something
people worry about.

But there is one
thing that happens very commonly when you do RKR.

You generate a
potential curve that instead of looking like
this looks like that.
The inner wall tends to hook. And this is a common problem.

And it comes from blindly
using bV and g of V.

Keep in mind that you're
determining-- the outer wall is moving very fast.

So you're sampling
the energy levels. And the outer wall is
changing its position rapidly

with V. The inner wall is
mostly going up slowly. I mean, it's going up
vertically, not changing much.

And so, all of the
RKR is being stressed by trying to determine this
rapidly changing function

with perhaps incomplete,
perhaps defective data.

And you almost
always get a hook. And so, what you do is say,
OK, what is the functional

form for the inner wall? And you constrain the RKR to
have the right inner wall.

And that gives
better potentials. There are other
things that people do to improve on RKR potentials.

But one of the best
tests is, we have V of r.

And we automatically get
the J dependence of it. And so, we should
be able to calculate

from it g of V. b of V, d
of V, and many other things.

And now, RKR used g of V and
b of V to determine this.

But we have the potential--
now we do numerical integration of-- we solve for-- you
have a potential.

You find where the
energy levels are. Not by semi-classical
methods, but by integration

of the Schrodinger equation. And so, you can then
solve the problem

by numerical integration
and ask, well, do the calculated
values of quantities

obtained from the potential, are
they equal to the input values?

It's not a circle. If you are using semi-classical
methods to get this

and strictly quantum mechanical
numerical integration methods to invert back to the spectrum.

And the agreement
is astonishing. And so, that's an important
characteristic of RKR.
It works. It's a trivial program.

Even in 1970, it took seconds
to run and on a big computer.

But big computer in
those days, yes, they were pretty slow compared--
whereas Frank [INAUDIBLE],,

or the numerical integration
takes hundreds of times longer.

Now, both take no time at all
on little-- on your laptops.

So it's a wonderful procedure. And it makes using models
in diatomic molecules

completely stupid unless
you have essentially no data

and you want to take
a little fraction-- fragmentary data and get
a little bit of leverage

to extrapolate or
interpolate hoping to find more so that
you can verify things. But the RKR is just
a wonderful thing.

And often, you see people still
writing papers questioning the validity of RKR
potentials and saying, well,

you really ought to take this
to a higher order of WKB. And you can do that. And in fact, that's built
into Leroy's programs.

So it's not it's not
time to quit yet. But--

So are there other questions? Should I come up with a

And so, basically, you can

This is-- you can pretty
